trial_identification.studytitle: School-based eating disorder prevention: A pilot effectiveness trial of teacher-delivered Media Smart
trial_identification.scientifictitle: School-based eating disorder prevention: A pilot effectiveness trial of teacher-delivered Media Smart

interventions.interventions: Media Smart is an 8-lesson school-based program that aims to develop student skills in media literacy. Each lesson is of 50 minutes duration and is delivered at the rate of 2 lessons per week, thus taking 4 weeks in total. The lessons involve a range of interactive learning activities aimed at promoting media literacy, including before and after examples of airbrushing, investigation of stereotypical presentations of men and women in the media and students writing a letter to an advertising company to express concerns about the use of unhealthy advertising messages. The program will be delivered by teachers who have attended a 90-minute workshop in delivery of Media Smart.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Shape Concern and Weight Concern subscales (12 items) from the Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire (EDE-Q; Fairburn & Beglin, 1994)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Dieting: Dutch Eating Behaviour Questionnaire ? Restraint Scales (10 items:Van Strien, Frijters, Bergers, & Defares, 1986)
Body dissatisfaction: Eating Disorder Inventory - Body Dissatisfaction (10 items: Garner, Olmstead, & Polivy, 1983)
Media internalisation: Sociocultural Attitudes Towards Appearance Questionnaire-3, (9 items: Thompson et al., 2004)
Ineffectiveness: Eating Disorder Inventory - Feelings of Ineffectiveness (10 items: Garner et al., 1983)
Self-esteem: Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (10 items: Rosenberg, 1965)
Weight-related peer teasing: McKnight Risk Factor Survey (8 items: Shisslak et al., 1999)

trial_design.concealment: School classes are allocated to either Media Smart or control group by the toss of a coin
trial_design.sequence: Randomisation done at the class level, as above

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: School of Psychology Flinders University GPO Box 2100 Adelaide, SA, 5000

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study aims to pilot how well a previously successful school-based eating disorder prevention program works when delivered by teachers rather than health professionals.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Flinders University Social and Behavioural Research Ethics Committee
